Literature Review: Social cognitive aging refers to the changes in cognitive processes and social interactions that occur as individuals age. The determinants of social cognitive aging are complex and multifaceted, involving both biological and environmental factors. This review aims to provide an integrated model of the determinants of social cognitive aging, focusing on the social cognitive resource (SCoRe) framework. The SCoRe framework posits that social cognitive resilience is determined jointly by capacity and motivational resources. Capacity refers to the individual's ability to process and respond to information, while motivational resources refer to the individual's motivation and expectation of reward or loss. The relationship between capacity and motivation is bidirectional, with changes in one influencing the other. Neurobiological aging, driven by genetic and environmental influences, is associated with broader sensory, neural, and physiological changes that are direct determinants of capacity as well as indirect determinants of motivation via their influence on expectation of loss versus reward and cognitive effort valuation. For example, a study by Verhaeghen et al. (2012) found that older adults showed reduced cognitive capacity due to age-related declines in processing speed and memory. This decline in capacity can lead to decreased motivation, as older adults may feel less capable of achieving their goals. On the other hand, motivation can also influence capacity, as individuals with higher motivation may be more likely to engage in cognitive training and practice to improve their cognitive abilities. A study by Hultsch et al. (2005) found that older adults with higher motivation were more likely to engage in cognitive training and showed improved cognitive performance. Contextual factors, such as relationship status, familiarity, and practice, are fundamental to understanding the availability of both types of resource. For example, a study by Carstensen et al. (1999) found that older adults with strong social relationships had better cognitive performance and were less likely to experience cognitive decline. In contrast, older adults with weak social relationships had poorer cognitive performance and were more likely to experience cognitive decline. The SCoRe framework also highlights the importance of ecological validity in understanding social cognitive aging. Ecological validity refers to the extent to which research findings can be generalized to real-world situations. A study by Salthouse (2010) found that older adults who participated in tasks that were ecologically valid (i.e., tasks that simulated real-world situations) showed better cognitive performance and were less likely to experience cognitive decline compared to older adults who participated in tasks that were not ecologically valid. In conclusion, the determinants of social cognitive aging are complex and multifaceted, involving both biological and environmental factors. The SCoRe framework provides a useful framework for understanding the relationship between capacity and motivation in social cognitive aging. Future research should focus on developing interventions that target both capacity and motivation, and on examining the ecological validity of research findings. By doing so, we can better understand the determinants of social cognitive aging and develop effective strategies for promoting social cognitive resilience in late adulthood.
